description: Network Monitoring System Dashboard (node, Snmp, BBox)

panels.description: Busy state of all CPU cores together
panels.title: CPU Busy

panels.description: System load  over all CPU cores together
panels.title: Sys Load

targets.legendFormat: TCP_inuse - Tcp sockets currently in use
UDPLITE_inuse - Udplite sockets currently in use
UDP_inuse - Udp sockets currently in use
FRAG_inuse - Frag sockets currently in use
RAW_inuse - Raw sockets currently in use
mem_bytes - TCP sockets in that state
mem_bytes - UDP sockets in that state
InMsgs -  Messages which the entity received. Note that this counter includes all those counted by icmpInErrors
OutMsgs - Messages which this entity attempted to send. Note that this counter includes all those counted by icmpOutErrors
InErrors - Messages which the entity received but determined as having ICMP-specific errors (bad ICMP checksums, bad length, etc.)
InErrors - UDP Datagrams that could not be delivered to an application
NoPorts - UDP Datagrams received on a port with no listener
InErrors Lite - UDPLite Datagrams that could not be delivered to an application
InSegs - Segments received, including those received in error. This count includes segments received on currently established connections
OutSegs - Segments sent, including those on current connections but excluding those containing only retransmitted octets
ListenOverflows - Times the listen queue of a socket overflowed
ListenDrops - SYNs to LISTEN sockets ignored
TCPSynRetrans - SYN-SYN/ACK retransmits to break down retransmissions in SYN, fast/timeout retransmits
RetransSegs - Segments retransmitted - that is, the number of TCP segments transmitted containing one or more previously transmitted octets
InErrs - Segments received in error (e.g., bad TCP checksums)
OutRsts - Segments sent with RST flag
CurrEstab - TCP connections for which the current state is either ESTABLISHED or CLOSE- WAIT
MaxConn - Limit on the total number of TCP connections the entity can support (Dynamic is "-1")
ActiveOpens - TCP connections that have made a direct transition to the SYN-SENT state from the CLOSED state
PassiveOpens - TCP connections that have made a direct transition to the SYN-RCVD state from the LISTEN state
established - TCP sockets in established state
fin_wait2 - TCP sockets in fin_wait2 state
listen - TCP sockets in listen state
time_wait - TCP sockets in time_wait state

panels.description: This metric represents the duration of a collector scrape performed by the Node Exporter. In other words, it measures how long it takes to collect data from various system metrics on a Linux host.
panels.title: Node Exporter Scrape Time

panels.description: This metric represents the count of SNMP collection durations. It indicates how many times the SNMP exporter has collected data from SNMP-enabled devices. Essentially, it tracks the number of collection events.
panels.title: Number of collection events

panels.description: This metric counts the total number of SNMP request errors encountered by the exporter. These errors can occur due to various reasons, such as invalid SNMP credentials, unreachable devices, or unsupported SNMP operations. Monitoring this metric helps identify issues with data retrieval.
panels.title: Total request errors

panels.description: This metric represents the sum of SNMP collection durations. It provides the total time spent collecting data from SNMP devices. The value is typically in seconds and reflects the cumulative time spent during all collection events.
panels.title: Time spent collecting metrics

panels.description: This metric tracks the total count of unexpected Protocol Data Unit (PDU) types received during SNMP communication. PDUs are the basic units of SNMP messages (e.g., GetRequest, GetNextRequest, etc.). Unexpected PDU types may indicate misconfigurations or issues with the SNMP device.
panels.title: Total PDU Errors

panels.description: This metric is a boolean value (0 or 1) that indicates whether the last configuration reload was successful.
panels.title: Last configuration reload

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

panels.description: Disk space used of all filesystems mounted
panels.title: Disk Space Used Basic

matcher.options: Idle - Waiting for something to happen
Iowait - Waiting for I/O to complete
Nice - Niced processes executing in user mode
Steal - Time spent in other operating systems when running in a virtualized environment
System - Processes executing in kernel mode
User - Normal processes executing in user mode

targets.legendFormat: System - Processes executing in kernel mode
User - Normal processes executing in user mode
Nice - Niced processes executing in user mode
Iowait - Waiting for I/O to complete
Steal - Time spent in other operating systems when running in a virtualized environment
Idle - Waiting for something to happen

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

targets.legendFormat: Apps - Memory used by user-space applications
PageTables - Memory used to map between virtual and physical memory addresses
SwapCache - Memory that keeps track of pages that have been fetched from swap but not yet been modified
Slab - Memory used by the kernel to cache data structures for its own use (caches like inode, dentry, etc)
Cache - Parked file data (file content) cache
Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

targets.expr: sum by(instance) (irate(node_cpu_guest_seconds_total{instance="$node",job="$job", mode="user"}[1m])) / on(instance) group_left sum by (instance)((irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{instance="$node",job="$job"}[1m])))
targets.legendFormat: Guest - Time spent running a virtual CPU for a guest operating system

targets.expr: sum by(instance) (irate(node_cpu_guest_seconds_total{instance="$node",job="$job", mode="nice"}[1m])) / on(instance) group_left sum by (instance)((irate(node_cpu_seconds_total{instance="$node",job="$job"}[1m])))
targets.legendFormat: GuestNice - Time spent running a niced guest  (virtual CPU for guest operating system)

title: Network Monitoring
